urn:contentItem:5WNS-FDJ1-F11P-X41G-00000-00BINDRA: Are we seeing Facebook's 'M-Pesa' moment? Bankers sit up straight2019-07-28T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:25:03ZLexisNexisBINDRA: Are we seeing Facebook's 'M-Pesa' moment? Bankers sit up straightSUNNY BINDRA

Traditional banking and payments are broken. They are too cumbersome, too expensive.

In every talk I have given to banking groups in recent years, I have warned them that future competition will be nothing like what they have been used to.
The biggest threats to their future will not come from other bankers, because those guys are just as confused and hesitant and invested in the past; it will not even come from Fintechs, because those guys can be co-opted to become the allies of incumbent banks — for those with the vision to partner up.


No, the greater threat will come from something that's right under the bankers' noses: Big Tech.
The giant companies that power everything that's happening right now on the smartphones of bankers are the ones who will pose the existential danger.
Why? Because they hold so many of the crucial cards. They have global brand acceptance.
DIGITAL CURRENCY
They have the cuffs on billions, not millions, of people. They have the best brains working for them. They have made the greatest investments in the new technologies that will change the game.
All it will take is for them to make their first foray into payments and money transfers, and the Trojan horse will be in motion …
Well, that first foray just happened. Facebook announced its new digital currency, Libra.
On the face of it, this is nothing. It's just an in-house payment system. You know when you visit a theme park or casino, you usually have to change your dollars and shillings into tokens, use those to pay for stuff, then change what's left over back into real money as you leave? Isn't this just that?
Ahem. True, Facebook would want you to buy Libra coins using your dollars, use those coins to send money to any other Facebook user in the world, and turn your Libra hoard back into dollars any time you like.
E-COMMERCE
This is not a cryptocurrency; it's tightly controlled and designed to be stable against major currencies, and it's meant to be bought for convenience, not speculation. Pretty harmless, huh?
Think again. Here's what else Libra might be doing. It might become a no-fee way to send money across borders. It could become a major payments platform for e-commerce, sidestepping credit-cards and bank fees.
And since Facebook controls not just its own dominant social network, but also Instagram and WhatsApp, that could give it billions of possible daily money movements in a stroke.
The launch goal is to handle 1,000 transactions per second. Also, the blockchain platform underlying Libra could allow smart-contract settlements, loans, insurance …
I trust every banker in the world is now sitting up straight.
DATA SAFETY
Oh wait, you say. Regulators will never permit this. They've already expressed concerns. And this is Facebook, of Cambridge Analytica notoriety, reeling from a record $5 billion fine for failing to protect user data. It won't be allowed.
I would just remind you that, that is exactly what you said about M-Pesa 10 years ago, bankers …
Facebook has actually been quite clever about this. The Libra blockchain is controlled by 100 members of a separate, neutral foundation.
Facebook is keen to assure everyone that the treasure-trove of financial data that Libra will throw up will not be accessible to it (unless perhaps you give it permission … ahem again).
Libra may never get off the ground, regardless. Central bankers will have deep jitters about a borderless currency on this scale. We will find out in the coming months.
CHANGE
But whether Libra flies or not is emphatically not the point. If you're a banker, don't hang your future on this thing getting blocked; understand what's really going on. Traditional banking and payments are broken.
They are too cumbersome, too expensive, too old-world for customers in a click-click-done world. Libra is just one way forward. Many others will pop up. Some of them will fly. Some of them may kill you.
What any bank should be doing right now is sitting down to work out what the hell to do to compete in a world where secure financial transactions will be completed in seconds, not weeks.
Top teams should be preoccupied with how to remove frictions, improve speeds, design smart interfaces, reduce fees. That will involve fresh thinking, new talent and many collaborations.
And if you haven't been doing that with any seriousness, tomorrow morning is already too late. Otherwise, prepare to be "M-Pesa-ed" all over again, bankers. It will hurt.
Sunny Bindra's new book, The Bigger Deal, is now on sale. www.sunwords.com

urn:contentItem:4HJC-8XH0-TX4F-533M-00000-00Biotechnology. SLIM APPETITE FOR BIOTECH FIRMS2005-11-11T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:25:03ZLexisNexisECONOMY, BUSINESS & FINANCEPg. 44Biotechnology. SLIM APPETITE FOR BIOTECH FIRMSJacqui Pile

Biotechnology

SLIM APPETITE FOR BIOTECH FIRMS

In 1996 scientists at the Council for Scientific & Industrial Research (CSIR), discovered a compound that piqued the interest of large pharmaceutical companies. CSIR researchers investigating the hoodia plant (used for generations by the Kalahari San to stave off hunger and thirst on long journeys) found that it could be used as an appetite suppressant.

They isolated the active ingredient, known as P57, which for pharmaceutical companies represented the key to fighting obesity in rich countries - and a slice of the R60bn weight-loss market.

The CSIR passed their work on to a British company, Phytopharm, for further development. Phytopharm's share price rocketed as traders anticipated rich returns from a drug that would revolutionise the slimming market. The company then sold the exclusive global rights to commercialise the drug to Pfizer for $21USm.

"Africa lost out on a huge biotech opportunity," says Suza Adam, initiator of Lifesparks Biobasics, SA's first biotech partnering forum. "It highlighted the lack of business acumen in some of our research institutions."

Since then, government has become wise to the potential of biotech in SA. A strategy to boost the sector has been implemented, there are tighter patent laws and regulations around the use of biodiversity, and increases in funding have helped put the sector on the radar screens of US analysts - though many at home still need convincing.

"The US has an army of analysts who value biotech companies on the strength of their technology," says Shimoda Biotech CEO Greg Gilbert. "Here analysts tend to stick to financials."

Overseas, investors are piling into biotech stocks. Publicly traded biotech companies across the globe saw revenues increase 12% in 2004 to $54,6bn, according to a report by Ernst & Young. Biotech is now starting to rival traditional pharmaceutical firms, which are big cash generators.

Biotech firms are also working smarter. The Ernst & Young report shows that in 2004 the pharmaceutical industry spent about $50bn on research & development (R& D), compared with the $16bn spent by publicly traded US biotech companies, and an estimated $20bn spent by the global biotech industry.

In spite of its large R& D expenditure, the pharmaceutical industry's new drug approvals have been declining steadily while biotechs have accounted for a rising share of new drug approvals over the past five years. (See graph).

And as investors become less squeamish about genetically modified crops, cloned animals and stem cell research, biotech is set to become the next big tech boom. "Compared with information technology, biotech is far more hi-tech, far more complex and therefore far riskier for investors," says Adam. "But it holds more potential than the tech boom of the late 1990s."

SA's biotech industry is still embryonic. With about 50 core biotech companies, none of them listed, the country is not yet a real rival to other developing markets such as India, which now ranks in the top 10 biotech countries.

"Development has been random and crosses many disciplines," says Mark Fyvie, CEO of Cape Biotech, a government-funded body that promotes biotech development. "Most companies could be described as medium tech and product-orientated, rather than cutting-edge technology companies."

But he says SA is starting to develop pockets of excellence.

For one, SA has unique and rich biodiversity. This makes bioprospecting - screening natural plants for compounds with commercial potential - one area in which SA can compete.

SA also has a high prevalence of diseases such as Aids, tuberculosis and malaria, which are not always given sufficient attention by the big pharmaceutical companies, says Fyvie. These diseases can create local demand for a range of biotech activities - from diagnostics and vaccines to clinical trials and drug development.

"We also have a strong clinical environment, low-cost R& D and First-World intellectual property rights," he says. "That makes us an attractive destination for partnering."

But as with all biotech companies, early-stage financing remains a problem. "SA investors tend to be more risk-averse than, say, US investors," says Fyvie. "But we are seeing an increase in appetite for biotech investments."

New listings of health-care stocks such as Enaleni and Wellco on the Johannesburg Stock Exchange's AltX, the bourse for smaller firms, have helped establish a market for biotech ventures.

Thanks to government investment in the sector, investors are now willing to fund potential projects. "The flow of public funds into the biotech sector has helped lower the risk for private investors," says Fyvie. "Once riskier ventures gain traction, it has a knock-on effect on the rest of the industry."

There are now a number of venture capital firms and incubators willing to invest in biotech start-ups. "It's early days, but in SA over the next five years we will probably see five full-scale pharmaceutical companies on the JSE," predicts Fyvie. "We're just starting to climb the biotech curve."

urn:contentItem:5VR0-9BX1-JBKX-914P-00000-00Bipartisan Backlash Against Facebook Is Growing;Congress, Ftc Mulling Regulatory Actions That Pose Threat To Company’s Business Model2019-03-24T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:25:04ZLexisNexisBPg. 4Bipartisan Backlash Against Facebook Is GrowingCongress, Ftc Mulling Regulatory Actions That Pose Threat To Company’s Business ModelFelice MaranzThe Providence Journal

SOCIAL MEDIA

Facebook is contending with a growing array of bipartisan criticism and fresh regulatory issues which may pose increasing risk to its unique advertising-revenue-based business model, analysts say.

In recent days, President Donald Trump tweeted that the company is “sooo on the side of the Radical Left Democrats” \x97 even as Axios reported the president is doubling down on his Facebook spending strategy. New Zealand’s prime minister also singled out social media platforms in the wake of the Christchurch terrorist attacks.

Analysts are now flagging an opinion piece in The New York Times, by Rhode Island Rep. David Cicilline, a Democrat who’s chairman of the House Subcommittee on Antitrust, Commercial and Administrative Law. Cicilline wrote about the company’s “pattern of misconduct” and called for “an investigation into whether Facebook’s conduct has violated antitrust laws.”

“Investors should pay attention to the fact that there are people sitting in some very relevant seats that are attacking Facebook in ways that we have not seen in our almost two decade history of covering internet companies,” Stifel’s Scott Devitt wrote in a note.

Recent issues may be transient, Devitt said, and Facebook shares may prove cheap relative to the company’s earnings power, but “something feels very different to us this time.” He flagged Cicilline’s item as “further evidence that this may be more than a passing fad.”

Beacon Policy Advisors said in a note that “the potential action that regulators at the FTC could take against Facebook is far more significant” than rhetoric from Congress about reining the company in, whether via forced separation of Instagram or WhatsApp or by taxing companies that collect user data. A “substantial financial penalty,” along with other remedies, may be part of a settlement with the FTC in the coming weeks regarding user data provided to Cambridge Analytica, they said.

Facebook may also face more repercussions than other tech giants under scrutiny, like Alphabet Inc. and amazon.com, as its revenue model is uniquely ad-driven, Beacon said.

Facebook choosing “privacy above safety” may be a “trade-off not everyone will agree with,” MKM’s Rob Sanderson wrote in a note. He flagged Facebook’s moves toward inter-operability across messaging services and full encryption, and added that losing Chris Cox, whom he called Facebook’s second-most influential executive after Mark Zuckerberg, has been a catalyst for reexamining potential consequences.

Full encryption lets Facebook ensure technical privacy protection for all users, “including those that want to harm and exploit others,” which may become increasingly controversial, Sanderson said. Giving people better tools for finding and communicating with one another may boost problematic activity, while hurting Facebook’s ability to monitor “hate speech and other abuses.” And Facebook might be unable to gather as much user data, which has been “a huge enabler of better services and better ads.”

“While we think the stock remains inexpensive, mission-driven change often opens the door to potential revisions in outlook,” Sanderson warned.

It may take time for any government moves to kick in, if anything changes at all, Compass Point’s Isaac Boltansky said via email. “Big tech is facing an unprecedented global backlash from both ends of the ideological spectrum, but the policy response is still uncertain at this juncture,” he said. “There is broad bipartisan agreement that \x91something’ should be done, but as is often the case in Washington, defining \x91something’ is difficult.”

Boltansky raises questions about which companies may be covered and how varied business models and products will be addressed. Even so, he said, “recent policy developments \x97 from the FTC task force to Sen. [Elizabeth] Warren’s break-up proposal to President Trump’s comments \x97 should serve as a signal that Big Tech is at real risk of a policy paradigm shift following the next election.”

Facebook shares gained as much as 1.3 percent on Wednesday. The stock has rallied 25 percent year-to-date, versus a 13-percent gain for the S&P 500, though it has fallen almost 3 percent in the past year, compared to the market’s 4-percent rise.

The chief executives of Amazon, Apple, Facebook and Google last week fended off attacks about their dominance in testy exchanges with lawmakers that hinted at the kinds of novel enforcement actions or legislation that could eventually target the industry, ...

The chief executives of Amazon, Apple, Facebook and Google last week fended off attacks about their dominance in testy exchanges with lawmakers that hinted at the kinds of novel enforcement actions or legislation that could eventually target the industry, but experts say immediate change appears unlikely. The House Judiciary subcommittee on antitrust held its sixth in a series of hearings July 29 examining the power of digital platforms. Amazon's Jeff Bezos, Apple's Tim Cook, Facebook's Mark Zuckerberg and Google's Sundar Pichai all appeared via videoconference to defend their companies and answer questions from lawmakers about their business practices. The companies are currently being investigated by the U.S. Department of Justice, the Federal Trade Commission and nearly every state-level enforcer in the country for potential antitrust violations. The groundswell of attention reflects a sentiment that has emerged in recent years equating the titans of today's tech industry to John D. Rockefeller and Andrew Carnegie, who are often held up as archetypes of the type of monopolist that America's antitrust laws should target. Rep. David Cicilline, D-R.I., head of the House antitrust panel, evoked that comparison at the close of the hearing, saying "the names have changed, the story is the same." "Once again, their control of the marketplace allows them to do whatever it takes to crush independent business and expand their own power," Cicilline said. "This must end." Despite lawmakers' rhetoric, experts told Law360 it's unlikely they will attempt a wholesale breakup of any of the companies. That's partly because companies like Amazon and Facebook are so popular among their users, said Chad Elder, an antitrust partner with Bradley Arant Boult Cummings LLP. Although there is bipartisan support to clamp down on the sector, Elder said the looming election could make it difficult to reach a consensus. Republicans on the panel largely used the hearing to blast the heads of Google and Facebook with accusations about anti-conservative bias and favoring Democratic presidential candidate Joe Biden. President Donald Trump also tweeted ahead of the hearing that if Congress fails "to bring fairness to big tech," he would do it through executive order. He's already made such an attempt to address alleged censorship, issuing an order in May that asked the Federal Communications Commission to further define Section 230 of the Communications Decency Act, a provision that exempts websites from lawsuits as long as they employ reasonable moderation practices. A unit of the U.S. Department of Commerce sent a petition to the FCC last week making a formal request to jump-start a rulemaking. Democratic FCC Commissioners Jessica Rosenworcel and Geoffrey Starks have said they believe online content issues fall outside of the agency's jurisdiction. Nevertheless, Ajit Pai, the FCC's Republican chairman, on Monday announced that the commission would fulfill its obligation to seek public comment on the issue. "Long-standing rules require the agency to put such petitions out for public comment 'promptly,' and we will follow that requirement here," Pai said. "I strongly disagree with those who demand that we ignore the law and deny the public and all stakeholders the opportunity to weigh in on this important issue." There has also been bipartisan support in the Senate for legislation that would update Section 230. But it's not clear what impact the efforts will ultimately have, if any. "On some level, the hearings may amount to nothing more than political venting, a shot across the bow of Big Tech firms that they are being scrutinized more closely than they previously realized," Elder said. Threatening Breakups There have been calls for more robust antitrust enforcement for years, with critics often pointing to concentration levels and other economic data as indications the agencies haven't been doing enough. But the idea of breaking up the large technology platforms gained prominence in American politics last year when Sen. Elizabeth Warren, D-Mass., made the issue an important piece of her presidential campaign. Her proposal would see legislation mandating the breakup of Facebook, Amazon and Google and would bar operators of "platform utilities" — defined as companies with more than $25 billion in global revenue that offer online marketplaces, exchanges or platforms used by third parties to connect with customers — from participating on their own platforms. But R. Mark McCareins, a professor at Northwestern University's Kellogg School of Management and former co-head of Winston & Strawn LLP's global competition practice, said that breaking up companies through legislation is a risky proposition. He noted that there were calls to break up Walmart Inc. several years ago, but that its dominance in retail began to dwindle — in part because of Amazon's rise. Now Walmart has pivoted partly through acquisitions in the e-commerce space to better compete against Amazon. Walmart adapting and surviving shows that the marketplace can work on its own, McCareins said. "Once we start going down this road of attempting to legislatively reengineer large successful companies, it becomes a slippery slope," he said. Michael Carrier, a professor at Rutgers Law School, told Law360 that the hearing showed that lawmakers came prepared and were intent on making their points, frequently cutting off witnesses to get in some extra words. But he said he doesn't expect any immediate action to result from the hearing, or that legislation forcing a breakup of the companies is likely. The hearing could, however, provide additional support for those pushing enforcers to take action. "I see the hearing as consistent with the federal and state investigations of these companies and bipartisan attention in Congress," Carrier said. "My guess is that the agencies already felt pressure to act, and this will modestly increase that pressure." Targeting Past Deals Most calls for breakups of the platform companies have emphasized unwinding past acquisitions. In addition to probing the conduct of tech companies, the FTC is also currently studying past deals in the sector to see if enforcers have overlooked transactions that should have been challenged. During the July 29 proceeding, lawmakers grilled Zuckerberg extensively about the motivations behind Facebook's $1 billion purchase of Instagram in 2012. House Judiciary Committee Chairman Jerrold Nadler, D-N.Y., said internal documents uncovered during the probe show that Facebook inked the deal because it saw the photo-sharing app as a competitive threat. "This is exactly the kind of anti-competitive acquisition the antitrust laws were designed to prevent," Nadler said. Documents flashed during the hearing show communications between Zuckerberg and other executives discussing the rationale for the deal and the purchasing of startups more generally. Zuckerberg acknowledged at the hearing that Facebook saw Instagram as both a competitor and a complement to its services. But the FTC cleared the transaction under the Hart-Scott-Rodino Act's premerger notification process, and Zuckerberg contended the agency had access to the same documents Nadler referenced. Enforcers could still challenge the tie-up to force an unwinding, but McCareins said it hasn't been done many times before, making it a tall order. "Not only is there very little precedent for such an approach, but in rapidly changing markets, it is patently unfair to allow the regulators two bites at the apple," he said. "My suggestion is that the DOJ and FTC do a better job up front in the HSR process of understanding the technology at issue and how a particular deal could change the competitive landscape in coming years." Lawmakers confronted Bezos with questions about Amazon's $500 million purchase of Diapers.com in 2010, another deal the FTC reviewed and cleared at the time. Rep. Mary Gay Scanlon, D-Pa., said the documents the subcommittee has seen indicate that Amazon viewed the online seller of baby products as its main competitor in the sale of diapers. To combat pricing pressure, Scanlon said, Amazon "hatched a plot" to take out Diapers.com, slashing its prices for diapers below cost in order to undercut its rival. When the smaller site began to founder, she said, Amazon purchased the company and then raised the prices on diapers back up. "Your own documents make clear that the price war against Diapers.com worked," Scanlon said. But Rep. Jim Sensenbrenner, R-Wis., the ranking Republican on the antitrust subcommittee, concurred with Bezos during the hearing that consumers would not be helped if Amazon were forced to spin businesses off. Sensenbrenner also criticized the breakup several decades ago of AT&T by U.S. authorities, and said he did not support changing the antitrust laws. He did say, however, that he supports making sure the existing laws are enforced and that he has concerns about market dominance in the digital space, though the risk he pointed to was censorship and its potential impact on conservative consumers. Carrier told Law360 that it is unlikely Amazon would be forced to spin off Diapers.com, but "the evidence could be part of a monopolization claim involving predatory pricing." Bradley Arant's Elder noted that "pricing below cost to drive out a competitor or force it to merge are already clearly covered by existing antitrust law," meaning the DOJ already has the tools it needs to go after that type of conduct. Watching for Potential Abuse Concerns about Big Tech extend beyond the acquisition of potential competitors and into their powerful positions as gatekeepers of the platforms they run. Rep. Pramila Jayapal, D-Wash., hammered Bezos during the hearing about the treatment of third-party sellers that rely on Amazon's marketplace. She referenced a Wall Street Journal article suggesting Amazon employees use data from the sellers to help pick what products its private-label business should sell, contradicting testimony from an Amazon employee who spoke in front of the subcommittee last year. Bezos responded that Amazon has a policy against using seller-specific data when making decisions for its retail business, but said he couldn't guarantee it has never been violated by employees making decisions on their own. He also said Amazon imposed this policy voluntarily and that he knows of no other retailer with something similar. McCareins said it's premature to speculate about enforcers launching an enforcement action against Amazon based on allegations that a rogue employee violated its policy. It's also not clear if the government would be able to win such a case. "These are issues that will only be addressed through discovery," he said. Elder said it's unlikely Amazon would be forced to sell off its private-label business, but that Congress could pass legislation to impose regulations on the company's business practices. This could, for example, provide some separation between the retail and marketplace businesses. The allegations against Apple, meanwhile, center on its App Store and the power the company wields over the distribution of software that runs on its devices. Lawmakers during the hearing raised concerns similar to those from proposed classes of developers and consumers suing Apple alleging monopolization based on the fees collected and restrictions imposed through the store. Rep. Hank Johnson, D-Ga., questioned Cook about the control Apple has over the app ecosystem, including the commissions it collects and the rules it imposes on developers, such as mandating that most apps use Apple's own payment system. But Cook insisted Apple faces competition for developers, who can choose to create apps for any number of other devices and operating systems, such as Android or Windows. On the handset side, there's a "street fight for market share," he said. He also faced questions about the introduction of Apple's Screen Time app, which allows parents to track and control the amount of time kids spend on their devices, and the subsequent removal of several apps from the store produced by third-party developers with similar functionality. Cook said the other apps were removed over safety and privacy concerns and that there are currently 30 other parental control apps in the store. But McCareins said the type of conduct that lawmakers are targeting from Apple and the other tech giants would make tough cases for enforcers to bring. He pointed to the DOJ's failed bid to block AT&T from purchasing Time Warner and a lack of precedent on challenges to vertical deals, which combine companies at different points in the supply chain. "I would be concerned that an overly aggressive court action against any one of these tech companies, absent compelling facts, would suffer the same fate" as the Time Warner challenge, he said. Cicilline accused Google of transforming itself from "a turnstile to the rest of the web" into a "walled garden that increasingly keeps users within its sites." He said the company now uses its position to identify competitive threats and crush them, including by allegedly stealing content and threatening to delist companies that complain. He also said Google has made it so that virtually any business that wants to be found on the internet has to pay Google a tax. Pichai insisted the company operates in "highly competitive and dynamic global markets, in which prices are free or falling and products are constantly improving." And he said Google's success depends on the success of the businesses that use its services. European enforcers have slapped Google with a total of €8 billion ($9.4 billion) in fines for abusing its dominance through its comparison shopping service, mobile operating system and search advertising business. But McCareins said it would be tough to bring such a case in the U.S., in part because the law requires precise definitions of markets being impacted by anti-competitive activity, and the lines between markets are not clear in search, online advertising and related spaces. "Applying those fundamentals to an ever-changing tech sector is a challenge for the government, especially given the dearth of existing judicial precedent on these issues," he said. --Editing by Alanna Weissman and Aaron Pelc.

June 26 -- The senators in question are Missouri Republican Josh Hawley, who you may remember as the champion of the proposed "Protecting Children from Abusive Games Act" (which would ban loot boxes in games aimed at kids), and Virginia Democrat Mark Warner.


In broad strokes, the politicians' proposed legislation, which has been dubbed the Designing Accounting Safeguards to Help Broaden Oversight and Regulations on Data Act (DASHBOARD Act), would force big tech companies to quantify exactly how much their users' data is worth and disclose the results publicly.
Senator Josh Hawley.
In order to avoid putting undue stress on a given company's operations, the Act would only require companies to perform this data value audit every 90 days. Furthermore, it won't be entirely up to the companies to determine data values; the SEC will be responsible for creating specific guidelines for them to follow. This should make the data calculation process a bit easier for corporations, while also ensuring they can't fudge numbers.
It remains to be seen whether or not the DASHBOARD Act will gain any traction, but the fact that it has bipartisan support right out of the gate is interesting, at the very least.

urn:contentItem:5VVR-F6N1-JCMN-Y1CC-00000-00Bipartisan Bill Tackles Shady Data Harvesting, Big Tech's Lies2019-04-10T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:25:03ZLexisNexisBipartisan Bill Tackles Shady Data Harvesting, Big Tech's LiesDominik Bosnjak

Apr 10, 2019( Android Headlines: http://androidheadlines.com Delivered by Newstex) A bipartisan bill introduced in the U.S. Senate earlier this week aims to put an end to the kind of shady data harvesting practices that have been running rampant in the Silicon Valley and beyond for well over a decade. Sponsored by Republican SenatorDeb Fischer and Democrat Mark Warner, the DETOUR Act[1]wants to make short work of user interfaces and technology design practices meant to take consumers on a ride of deception, tricking them into giving over their personal data to companies with over 100 million users. Short for the "Deceptive Experiences To Online Users Reduction Act," the legislation would have prevented the creation of Facebook and Google as we know them today had it been in force back when those two were but a couple of infants dreaming of monopolies and abuse of power[2]. The two Senators behind the initiative explained how they specifically wanted to address "dark patterns" with the DETOUR Act, referring to misleading design practices that essentially have tech companies lie to people, misrepresenting their need for certain privacy concessions to be made on the part of their users.

The bill draft proposed in the Senate forbids companies from building data-harvesting products aimed at pre-teens, prevents them from doing A-B testing without obtaining specific consent from users, and requires them to be subjected to independent audits meant to ensure they aren't devolving into evil corporations at least once per quarter. It's a remarkably pro-consumer piece of legislation, which is precisely why cynics don't expect it to get passed anytime soon, if at all. Intentional efforts aimed at limiting users' understanding of online services and their rights, particularly as those relate to their personal data, is one of the most alarming issues plaguing the modern Internet, Senator Fischer said in a prepared statement, concluding that she hopes the DETOUR Act is just the beginning of things to come in regards to online consumer protections in the country. More than just a page from the EU's book If all of that sounds familiar, it's because the DETOUR Act is essentially a lite version of the General Data Protection Regulation, that pesky set of laws that have been troubling honest-to-God data harvesters in Europe for about a full year now. It's notasstrict and its scope appears to be significantly reduced compared to GDPR but it's a clear sign of times for big tech[3] in the United States. The land of the free is unfortunately also the land where big corporations were free to exploit every drop of the general public's goodwill in recent times, which is what indirectly led to Facebook's Cambridge Analytica scandal, the privacy debacle that was the final nail in the Google+ coffin, etc. Despite being at its most polarizing point in recent memory, the state of mainstream politics in the U.S. still sees both the GOP and DNC easily agree Internet firms need to be regulated more aggressively, which would be an encouragingly remarkable example of bipartisanship if it wasn't primarily a reminder about how anti-consumer some of these multi-billion-dollar corporations have become. urn:contentItem:5V85-9FT1-JBHM-S025-00000-00Bipartisan data privacy bills offered in Senate; Markey and Blumenthal examine FTC's Facebook investigation2019-01-22T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:25:03ZLexisNexisBipartisan data privacy bills offered in Senate; Markey and Blumenthal examine FTC's Facebook investigation

January 18, 2019 | Maggie Miller Multiple members of Congress took aim at data privacy this week, with Sens. Amy Klobuchar (D-MN) and John Kennedy (R-LA) reintroducing legislation Thursday to protect the data of social media users, on the same day that two Democratic senators wrote to the Federal Trade Commission asking for information on how the ongoing partial government shutdown is impacting its investigation of Facebook's data privacy policies.

The Social Media and Consumer Rights Act, originally introduced by Klobuchar and Kennedy in April, would give social media users the right to "opt out" of data tracking and collection programs, along with requiring consumers to be notified of any breach of their information within 72 hours, and mandating social media terms of service agreements be written in "plain language." The bill was referred to the Senate Commerce Committee during the 115th Congress, where it was never marked up.

"Every day, companies profit off of the data they're collecting from Americans, yet leave consumers completely in the dark about how their personal information, online behavior, and private messages are being used," Klobuchar said in a statement. "Consumers should have the right to control their personal data."

Kennedy emphasized that he does not "want to regulate Facebook or any private social media company," but noted that "these platforms continue to compromise their users' private data."

"In today's world, private data is the equivalent of our personal identities, and companies need to know that they'll be held accountable when they violate the public's trust and compromise our private information," Kennedy said. "Our legislation does just that."

Sens. Edward Markey (D-MA) and Richard Blumenthal (D-CT) also expressed concern over social media data privacy, writing a letter to all five FTC commissioners on Thursday seeking information on how the partial government shutdown is affecting the FTC's investigation of Facebook. The investigation began last March following reports that consulting firm Cambridge Analytica obtained Facebook user data without consent in order to target political messages.

"We believe that the FTC should have the resources and plans necessary to resume its investigation once the Commission is funded," Blumenthal and Markey wrote. "When Americans' privacy is breached, they deserve a speedy and effective response. The government shutdown could have profound effects on the FTC's investigation beyond delays due to staff furloughs. Therefore, we strongly encourage the Commission to use every tool at its disposal in its investigation and we write to ensure that the FTC is able to address any detrimental impacts from the shutdown and conduct a fulsome investigation."

Blumenthal and Markey specifically asked for answers on what steps consumers should take if they are the victim of a data privacy invasion while the FTC is shut down; whether the FTC has an "efficient and effective plan" to resume its investigation of Facebook once the government reopens; and whether the FTC requires further resources to expedite the investigation.

On Wednesday, Sen. Marco Rubio (R-FL) introduced the American Data Dissemination Act, or the ADD Act, requiring the FTC to submit recommendations on privacy requirements to protect consumer data online. The bill would give the FTC the authority to "promulgate a final rule" on data privacy within 27 months of the bill's enactment if Congress fails to enact a law based on the FTC's recommendations.

"There has been a growing consensus that Congress must take action to address consumer data privacy," Rubio said in a statement. "However, I believe that any efforts to address consumer privacy must also balance the need to protect the innovative capabilities of the digital economy that have enabled new entrants and small businesses to succeed in the marketplace. That is why I am introducing the American Data Dissemination Act, which will protect small businesses and startups while ensuring that consumers are provided with overdue rights and protections."

Rubio continued, "it is critical that we do not create a regulatory environment that entrenches big tech corporations. Congress must act, but it is even more important that Congress act responsibly to create a transparent, digital environment that maximizes consumer welfare over corporate welfare."

Sen. Brian Schatz (D-HI) also plans to join the data privacy conversation, telling Inside Cybersecurity this week that he will reintroduce the Data Care Act "sometime in February." This legislation, originally introduced by Schatz and 14 other Senate Democrats in December, would require online service providers to "reasonably secure individual identifying data" and require "prompt" consumer notification in the event of a data breach, along with granting the FTC rulemaking authority to enforce the bill.

The measure was referred to the Senate Commerce Committee, where it did not receive a hearing. This committee however seems poised to resume discussion of data privacy during this Congress, with new Chairman Roger Wicker (R-MS) telling reporters this week that one of the panel's first hearings will focused on data privacy issues.

"Maintaining consumer trust and confidence in this marketplace is critical to preserving prosperous and thriving digital economy in the United States," Wicker said. "A priority of this committee will be to protect the privacy of consumers' data in a way that promotes industry transparency, consumer choice, and innovation." -- Maggie Miller (mmiller@iwpnews.com)

urn:contentItem:60PD-CHY1-F15W-H0ND-00000-00Bipartisan Policy Center Holds Webinar on Artificial Intelligence Strategy2020-08-25T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:25:03ZLexisNexisBipartisan Policy Center Holds Webinar on Artificial Intelligence Strategy

Bipartisan Policy Center Hosts Discussion On Artificial Intelligence Strategy

August 25, 2020 03:30 P.M.

SPEAKERS:

WORKDAY DC OFFICE HEAD CHANDLER MORSE

BROOKINGS INSTITUTION CENTER FOR TECHNOLOGY INNOVATION DIRECTOR NICOL TURNER LEE

CENTER FOR SECURITY AND EMERGING TECHNOLOGY STRATEGY DIRECTOR HELEN TONER

CENTER FOR A NEW AMERICAN SECURITY NATIONAL SECURITY FELLOW MARTIJN RASSER

NATIONAL SECURITY COMMISSION ON ARTIFICIAL INTELLIGENCE CHAIR ERIC SCHMIDT

REP. ROBIN KELLY (D-ILL.)

REP. WILL HURD (R-TEXAS)

[*]GRUMET: Good afternoon. I am Jason Grumet. It is a pleasure to welcome you to this afternoon's discussion with Representatives Will Hurd and Robin Kelly on a national AI strategy.

As I think everyone is well aware we are very focused at the moment in this country on our national politics but you know we at the Bipartisan Policy Center are also thinking about what awaits the roughly 500 winners of the November elections and recognize that we are going to have a country that remains in economic and health crisis while also facing a variety of complex challenges and the question that we, of course, are asking ourselves is how do we help our government governed in a divided nation. One of the key challenges that we know we are facing is the question of how we reap the benefits and manage the challenges of the continued move towards artificial intelligence.

For the past year, we have had the pleasure to work with Representatives Kelly and Hurd to develop a national strategy for artificial intelligence. We have held about half a dozen convenings where we have heard from over 80 different organizations and individuals from industry and academia, civil society organizations. Through this process, we have created four white papers on ethics, on research and development, on national security and workforce issues; these white papers we hope our forming the basis of a resolution that members of Congress will be talking about here in just a little bit. They will also be available on our website, and I think we are going to be posting them on the chat feature via YouTube.

Today we are going to focus a lot on both these recommendations but also on the process that Congressmen Hurd and Kelly are moving forward with to actually introduce a national resolution and before we move to that discussion it's really a great honor and privilege to have the ability to kick this off with Eric Schmidt who I think just about everybody in the world knows was the former CEO of Google. He is the chair of the National Security Commission on Artificial Intelligence, and he is going to lead off this conversation by sharing his view of what is the strategy for America to win in the effort to advance artificial intelligence, and so once Eric concludes his remarks we will then have a conversation with the representatives of Congress.

We will then move to a second panel where we drill down a little bit on some of the more key technical questions. After each of these interactions, we will have an opportunity for audience Q&A and just look to the live chat function on YouTube or Facebook or via Twitter with the hashtag BPClive. So with that opening stretch real pleasure Eric to turn over to you to set the stage for us.

SCHMIDT: Jason, thank you so much. You guys have done such a good job. I am really happy to be part of this. I wanted to start by saying that my comments here are as chairman of the National Security Commission for AI. This is a commission that was created by the Congress, and I am not speaking for any other groups that I am part of just literally this is this AI commission which was created by Congress in order to make some recommendations which interestingly are very similar to those of a Bipartisan Policy Commission, so I am really, really happy about that.

I also wanted to thank Representative Will Hurd and Robin Kelly, who I think both are on right now. They saw this earlier than the other folks in Congress, and frankly, there is a difference of understanding. Some people get it; most don't. These guys get it, and they worked pretty hard to help make this happen. When they talk, I think you will get a sense of why they are so good at what they do. And you know as I understand their view AI basically can play a sort of--they understand the role of both economic and social and you know for our security well-being, and so that vision led to the creation to the BPC to develop a strategy and a guide for the Congress which is sort of why we are all here.

It is interesting that in my wandering around, you know I am a scientist and technologist from Silicon Valley, there are a couple of groups that seem to be primarily in D.C. One is called the CSET, the Center for Security and Emerging Technology. Another one is the Center for New American Security, CNAS, both of whom seem to have an unusually large percentage of people who can cross the technology and the policy area. I have learned that this is a relatively small group, and these two are among the two or three of the top in the country, and they have been working very closely with the BPC.

So I just want to make sure everybody understands that the people who sort of are talking about this are inclusive, but fundamentally the group of people who are having this conversation is too small, and I want more of you to join one or more of these organizations. So basically BPC is now releasing their reports, which I am strongly recommending.

So basically what happened was the sort of lens of NASA(SP) security workforce and R&D is the same path that the National Security Commission for AI decided to take again I think showing that either common wisdom or common delusion hopefully common wisdom and we--it turns out that two of our commissioners who are Jason Matheny and Bob Work are actually associated with CSET and CNAS, big surprise there. So the long port of it is that the AI commission and will be we have a series of reports, we have a big one coming out early next year believes that holding a global leadership position in emerging technology is both an economic and national security imperative.

Both are important; people want to focus on one or the other but you actually need both, you need national security for obvious reasons, but you also need economic security and economic growth for all of the reasons that you could imagine, and the two go hand in hand. And I want to emphasize that we have rediscovered the basic fact that America is an innovator, and you have to have an innovation strategy in these areas. If you don't have an innovation strategy, your competitors the Europeans or more likely the Chinese and the Russians will take over some very important part of technology, and that is a really bad thing, so we want to be really, really clear.

And this leadership model that I am talking about then also gives our government access to the best in the world. Imagine if all of the really smartest encryption people and security people worked in China, and none of them are in the U.S. how would our military and our intelligence group do any of their function? They would always be beaten by the opponent. It is obvious that we need these as national resources, and in the American system, they tend to be in the private sector, they tend to be in universities, they tend to be in research labs. They are not controlled by the government, so the synergy between the universities and the government and the military and so forth and so on is critical in the American model.

I want to be very clear that we have a new competitive threat in the form of China. China is both our biggest strategic competitor and our current larger strategic partner. We have never faced this before in terms of the size and scale of the opponent and the collaboration. At the worst points in the Soviet Union, they were a third if you will of the GDP of America. China is on its way to surpass us in many, many ways, and they are cleverly run in a way that is different from the way we would ever want to be run, but we need to take them seriously. I have spent 15 years dealing with China, mostly on the losing side of negotiating with their government. I take them very, very seriously, and I encourage everyone else to do as well.

So the thing about it is they are going to end up with a bigger economy, more R&D investments, better quality research, wider applications of technology, and a stronger computing infrastructure. How is that okay? It is clearly not okay. Right? We have got to act, and the good news is we have time, and if you follow the thinking of the BPC and the AI Commission and some of the other affiliated groups, I think you will see that there is a way for us to do this. But if we don't act now in 10 or 20 years, we are going to say oh, my God, how could we have is this?

And the Chinese model is different in the form of I am going to use my own phrase here it is a sort of vision of high-tech authoritarianism which is incompatible with the way America works. I am not saluting it, I am not endorsing it in any way, but I am telling you to take it seriously, right? And it has benefits from the standpoint of a strategic execution which we need to have a good answer to and so obviously if China achieves market dominance and critical technologies it is the same argument. How would you like it if the majority of all of the things that you used during our friendly pandemic here sorry that was not a good joke for Chinese-controlled rather than U.S.? I mean, think about how difficult the pandemic is already and imagine if we were dependent on other people in this sort of horrific way.

So we have to provide a model of high-tech democracy that works, and I am concerned I will say it clearly that we collectively have not yet offered that. I think if you read the BPC reports you will see the list of actions that we have to take which I will highlight in a minute, but we seem to have forgotten in our political narratives that we need some things in order to keep winning and that winning is crucial for our economy, the stock market all of the kind of things that we care about.

And furthermore, this sort of foundation of high-tech economy is also our--our foundation of our freedoms which I take very seriously the freedom to associate, the freedom to think, the freedom of speech and so forth and so on. This technology can be shifted in the other way where it can become oppressive, and that is not acceptable to Americans, it is not acceptable to us, not acceptable to me. So--so for all of those reasons we have to provide real alternatives that are competitive, global and win in the marketplace, and that requires a refocusing on key areas of technology which we have either forgotten about, we found boring, or we haven't funded enough.

So think of it as technology leadership is a dual path, we have to protect our innovations, nobody wants their stuff stolen that is obviously not okay, but we have to innovate against our competitors, right? It is always better to run faster than your competitors and leave them behind. All of the other strategies blocking strategies or so forth they may feel good for a little while, but ultimately because of network effects and other things in competition, they end up staying around, and it becomes a real problem. We have to move faster.

So let what happens is that people say it's an arms race; that's too simplistic. The best outcome in my view is if the tech firms can outcompete their global competition to create network platforms on a global basis, that's a huge win for America and by the way if you care about the stock market, the gains of the stock market have largely been because the leading tech firms each of those establishes a global network platform which I can describe if you are interested in it and those things are at risk with the devolution with China, so it is a tricky set of issues.

So let me refer to, and I will see if I can finish up with a couple of comments the three AI reports that the BPC has published that at least I have seen one on R&D, one on national security, one on the workforce. On the R&D, it's pretty obvious that we need to increase our R&D spending, at least in critical areas. So if you are not familiar with where we are in R&D funding at the federal level we are down to a number pre-Sputnik we are roughly 0.7 percent of GDP, and that number has been as high as 2 percent, 2.5 percent. It is important that that number increases because that money doesn't come from anywhere else. It can't be made up by private philanthropy, it can't be made up from corporations, and yet it is the federal government in particular through its actions with the scientific community and working with U.S. universities that has invented things that ultimately led to things like the smartwatch and GPS and so forth and so on and obviously the Internet. We need to place some big bets on these t hings on these areas, and we need to address this funding and the BPC agrees with this.

We also need--we need to identify some--some research areas for national security and we should prioritize those. I am very worried about some new forms of encryption and some new algorithms that are coming out, and again we need to stay focused on making sure that we keep everything safe. The second paper that BPC talks about spends a lot of time on the question of human operators and AI systems. Let me give you an example to make the point.

We have a doctrine which I fully support in America that it is human in the loop. So here you are, the time is crunched, everything is happening incredibly quickly, and the AI system says press the button. Do you really think the human is going to have the kind of judgment and quality of thinking and insight to say let me debate the accuracy of the AI system while this thing is coming right at me? This is a very complicated problem that Jason and his team have really sort of addressed and it is one that we are going to have to spend an awful lot of time, there are a lot of AI issues as well, and particularly the high-stakes situations that we find in defense and security are of concern because everything gets compressed.

The military talks about something called the (INAUDIBLE) which is observe and operate and it is calculated around human reaction. In the AI system, this stuff can occur faster than humans can react. How do we deal with that problem? There is obviously all sorts of questions about testing and evaluation that we need to focus on. And then the third focus that BPC has is around basically AI talent. We need more people doing AI; we need to get the smartest people in the rest of the countries to come to America to do AI here because there are--there are incredibly excellent people. We want all of them here, and we don't want them in the competitor countries, and we need to figure out a way to sort of keep them both safe and also keep our national security through that process.

The report represent--highlights the critical role that immigrants and the children of immigrants have played in founding and leading U.S. technology companies. I can say that from my own experience, given that one of the cofounders of Google was foreign-born. I want America to win. I think every single person who is participating in this conversation. I know that our congressional leaders want us to win. I want a strategy to win.

I am concerned I will use my own framing now that we are still doing too many reactive things rather than saying here is a global way to win my summary which is very consistent with the BPC's recommendations is that we need to invest in AI, invest in AI research, make sure the ethics are right, invest in our talent, create new industries and jobs and have American companies be the ones that dominate us globally. I just don't see any other path.

The scenario where the world gets split and the Chinese in charge of this area and the one that we are in charge of is not an acceptable one. It is too dangerous for America, and I suspect you all when you read their reports you will agree with their conclusions and I--I think, and I think the BPC would like the Congress and the executive branch to adopt these recommendations as quickly as possible and I strongly urge everybody to do so.

Thank you so much, Jason, for introducing me here. What can I do to help, and again I cannot say enough good things about you guys have done.

GRUMET: Well, Eric, really appreciate both the perspective but also the generosity of your time and spirit and the service on the National Security Commission. I think it is an incredibly important and generous thing that you are doing.

We do have time for a couple of questions, and not surprisingly, this is a somewhat more tech-savvy crowd then we often get at BPC, so I have a bunch to choose from, I'm only going to be able to probably take about two. So let me start out Eric one of the questions a couple of the questions are about this question of kind of priority and focus and so if I could summarize I think the question is should the U.S. be moving faster in some sectors than others to deploy and develop AI systems or should we be just kind of pursuing all of these ideas on kind of parallel pathways?

SCHMIDT: You know there's an explosion going on in terms of research in all of these areas. I think many of them will be taken care of in the market. So if you are a business and you need better analytics for selling things that is a problem that is both solve and where you will pay employees $1 million a person amazing salaries because the economic return to you is so--I think that is going to happen.

I think we should focus on the federal government and the state governments and, in particular, our national security area because they are the business incentives are not the same, but the importance is just as high if not more important. That is where I think your emphasis has been; I think that is where ours is. We need to retool, reimagine whatever it is we need more people who understand this who are part of every aspect of the software and security systems in America.

GRUMET: So I think let me ask you one more question which is really a perfect on-ramp to the next panel, and that is if you could wave a magic wand and have Congress enact one specific AI-related policy what would it be and why?

SCHMIDT: Find a way to double the funding for research in America over a five-year period or less in a way that doesn't take from everyone else, so where it's a real improvement in available funds. There are things that the federal government is the only potential funder of and I am including federal government, I am including the DOD, I am including the national security industry, etc. We need more money because money does drive the signals around the hiring, building organizations, making experiments, and so forth.

GRUMET: Well, again, I really appreciate your time and perspective, and we certainly a course will be taking you up on the offer to stay in touch since these are important and parallel exercises.

Now my pleasure is to turn to two people who have been kind of the inspiration for this exceptional amount of work that we have been able to do over the last few months that is Congressmen Will Hurd and Robin Kelly. I think while they need no introduction just to remind you that Congressman Hurd represents Texas 23. He is the ranking member on the Subcommittee of Intelligence and Modernization and Readiness. Congressman Kelly represents the second district in Illinois. She serves on the House Energy and Commerce Committee and it has really been a terrific pleasure to work with both of you and also with your exceptional staff over the last year as we have tried to help you design this process.

And I guess I just want to start out before getting kind of into any weeds maybe with you Congressman Hurd what do you want the American public to know how AI is or will be affecting our lives?

HURD: Artificial intelligence is going to impact every single point of our industries, of our lives, of our economy as--as Eric had eloquently said we are in a--a--a struggle with the communist party of China and there's a role for all of us to play and I think the federal government has a role. We can help accelerate innovation, and then there are ways to increase that research dollar.

It is by actually making the federal government more efficient, and one of the things I have worked on since I have been in Congress is IT procurement. It's not a sexy topic, but when you make the government run better and cheaper, you can use that savings sort other things and--and specifically for innovation. We can be bringing these kind of technology into the government so that the government is using these tools that we were talking about and Congress is uniquely positioned to manage the trade-offs that we are going to have to deal with with new technology and a technological explosion.

And so you know a lot of times we were review about the impact this is going to have to our current way of life; it is going to be destructive period full stop but can we take advantage of this technology before it takes advantage of us? And I want to make sure that English and the dollar continues to be the dominant in this country not Mandarin (INAUDIBLE). So these are and--and I would say in my short time in Congress we have seen members realize and appreciate the importance of these issues and so you know the fact that the National Security Commission on AI was created and they recognize that and then also what we are doing now.

So it is great to be doing this with Robin. Shout out to BPC Michelle, and John from BPC have been fantastic in this, and it is a pleasure to have--have Eric kick off such an important occasion.

GRUMET: Representative Kelly same question to you in addition to Will's 2 A.M. voicemails what convinced you to join this exercise and what do you want the general public to be thinking about?

KELLY: Well, you said the right thing, Will's 2 A.M. voicemails. Just us working together when I was the ranking, and he was the chair of the IT task force, and I think I (INAUDIBLE) our first but somewhere close we had a hearing on artificial intelligence so when he called and asked you know would I be a part of this project I said definitely yes because AI is not the future it is here with us now affecting our world.

GRUMET: So Will and I think Eric shared with us you know the view of the important work being done by the National Security Commission, the Trump administration put together an executive order on AI that I think was well received and informed a lot of our work. Talk a little bit about what kind of distinguishes this effort, why were you interested in bringing this kind of group together for a congressional?

HURD: So--so Congress has a unique role to play and--and what we want to do from these convenings and the white papers and the recommendations from the white papers is put that together, and I think we will start with a resolution that recognizes the bipartisan accomplishments in AI policy that is happened under the previous administration and the current administration.

And then we also need to assert Congresses role in establishing national priorities, funding specific research like--like Eric was talking about and we also have to stop talking about sustaining cooperation with our allies. This is not just about the public and the private sector in the United States of America working together, we have to work with our allies in order to deal with China. An authoritarian country is always going to have more data than us. They don't care about civil liberties and so we in order to--to beat them at their game we are going to need more data, or we are going to need algorithms to that work on--on less data and that is one of the things that we talk in our papers.

And so we also want to try to identify a comprehensive strategy to make sure we retain global leadership in artificial intelligence, and we tried to focus this effort over four pillars workforce development, national security, research, and development and then ethics, that is the paper that is coming out today.

We want our democratic values to drive this new technology, to drive this new tool not that of an authoritarian government like the Chinese government. And so this is one, a nod to all of the great work it is trying to put priorities down the road, and it is a framework from which future Congresses can work from. Regardless of who the next administration is going to be after this upcoming election, this is going to have to be a major issue, and major effort to make sure we maintain American dominance in advanced technology.

We have been doing that since the end of World War II and if anybody who thinks that the government the federal government can't do it I would say look to prior to World War II about one in eight folks in the military were malnourished or excuse me one in eight in the entire country was malnourished, and they couldn't even join the military. We addressed that with a national food program.
